Peter, it's great to hear that you've found our work useful.  We are
always=
 happy to receive positive feedback.  We also like your demos
and from what=
 I've seen you could easily pursue a Ph.D. if you wanted
to.  Have you ever=
 considered going to graduate school for a Ph.D.?

ken

--- In neat@yahoogr=
oups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrote:
>
> I agree that=
 all the re-querying will get expensive. In fact running 
> such an evoluti=
on, in the matter of computational effort, that would 
> come as close as e=
xhaustive search, but I think there is something 
> beatuful in the way it =
is done. The CPPN can be re-queried each N 
> timesteps or when some criter=
ia in the environment is met. 
> 
> You know, I actually changed my entire =
phylosophy about EC since your 
> last paper about NS came out. I am about =
to add dynamic re-quering to 
> the CPPN->HyperNEAT substrates, while being=
 in Novelty Search. 
> 
> I don't really have to say too much good words, b=
ut it is obvious, NS 
> avoids all deception and it reaches solutions that =
FS has no hope to 
> reach. Great work, you people over there in the Eplex =
group! Cheers 
> to Ken, David, Joel and Jason! I am not a PhD or anything =
like that, 
> I am just a bulgarian freelancer but I really admire what you=
 have 
> done in this area. 
> 
> Peter 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, =
"Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter, I think re-querying the=
 CPPN over time is a great idea.  
> We've
> > talked about it in our resea=
rch group but we don't have any ongoing
> > projects with it, and I don't k=
now of any.  The only downside is 
> that
> > all that querying will get ex=
pensive.  However, it's very 
> interesting
> > because it means that the l=
earning rules themselves become 
> distributed
> > in a pattern, and are "m=
ade up" by HyperNEAT rather than being
> > preselected by the experimenter.=

> > 
> > The CPPN might also be able to output Hebbian parameters; althoug=
h
> > that is less groundbreaking, though it might work well.
> > 
> > ken
=

> > > Hi all,

> > > It is an interesting idea to=
 see what if the phenotypes produced 
> by the 
> > > CPPNs change over the=
ir lifetime. There are two approaches to 
> this: the 
> > > CPPN can outpu=
t hebbian learning parameters to the connections or 
> the

be re-queried every time step, so the connections will 
> be

ly different every time, depending on the environment,

 be input to the CPPN.
